et: Middle English {it}slipir, sliper{/it} "causing something to slide or slip, deceitful," going back to Old English {it}slipor, sliper,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*slip-ra-{/it} (whence also Old High German {it}sleffar{/it} "sloping downward"), adjective derivative from the base of Germanic {it}*sleipan-{/it} (strong verb) "to slide, slip" (whence Middle Dutch {it}slīpen{/it} "to smooth, polish, sharpen," Middle Low German, "to glide, sink, slip," Old High German {it}slīfan{/it} "to slide, pass away, decline"), of uncertain origin

The adjective {it}slipper{/it} has been effectively replaced by its derivative {et_link|slippery|slippery}, though the former was in existence in dialect late enough to be noticed by the Survey of English Dialects, which recorded it in Devon and Cornwall (see {it}Survey of English Dialects: The Dictionary and Grammar,{/it} Routledge, 1994, s.v.). — The Germanic verb has been compared with Greek {it}olibrón,{/it} glossed by Hesychius with {it}olisthērón{/it} "slippery," though the assumption of an Indo-European etymon {it}*h{inf}3{/inf}slib-ro-,{/it} with both {it}*b{/it} and a laryngeal preceding a sibilant, seems questionable. Parallel to {it}*sleipan-{/it} is a verb {it}*sleupan-{/it} "to creep, glide," which has been explained as a secondary formation based on near-synonymous {it}*sleuban-{/it} (see {et_link|slip:5|slip:5}, {et_link|sleeve|sleeve}). As all these bases are ultimately of phonesthemic origin and can presumably be reshaped by variation of phonesthemic origin, it is difficult to disentangle inheritance from innovation. Compare {et_link|slip:1|slip:1}.
